thread.title: Ola journeys to Woodland to face once-beaten Wolfpack
thread.title_full: Ola journeys to Woodland to face once-beaten Wolfpack

author: Neighbor Newspapers (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Ola journeys to Woodland to face once-beaten Wolfpack
text: by Bill Baldowski Neighbor Newspapers October 02, 2015 06:27 PM | 217 views | 0 | 0 | | Ola steps into its first region , subregion B game Friday against the team which is setting the early pace in that subregion.The Ola Mustangs bring a 2-2 record into Wolfpack county as they face 4-1 Woodland, which recorded its first subregion win two weeks ago in a 10-7 defensive struggle against Dutchtown.Ola, which has wins over Morrow, 41-6 and McIntosh, 26-0, has lost to Locust Grove, 37-20 and Lamar County, 27-14.Woodland head coach Steve Davenport said the win over Dutchtown was a real boost for his squad after their loss to the Bulldogs last season.“Having a bye last week came at a good time for our team as we had a few nagging injuries which, having the week off, should have us in better shape to face Ola,” he said.Ola head coach Jared Zito described his team using a “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” scenario, referring to the famous story by Robert Lewis Stevenson.“Due to our having to play numerous sophomores as well as a good number of seniors and juniors who are in their first season of varsity football competition this year, it seemed we were looking at two different teams from the first to the second half or one game to another,” he said.“As we go into the second half of the season facing subregion opponents, we have got to play well in both halves of a game as things will get tight from now on in subregion play.”Ola’s defense faces one of its toughest tasks of the season in trying to limit Woodland’s offensive yardage which, from a rushing standpoint, relies on Wolfpack senior running back Deangelo Albert.Davenport said Albert has compiled more than 700 yards rushing already this season, including a 156-yard effort against Dutchtown.“Deangelo has had a great year for us,” Davenport said.Zito agreed, saying Ola’s defense has to stop Woodland’s big play capabilities, “which means stopping Albert before he gets going.”However, Woodland’s defense might experience and equally difficult task in trying to limit Ola’s primary rushing threat, sophomore running back Chris Rodriquez who has already rushed for more than 500 yards this season and scored eight touchdowns.“Chris combines size with good, hard-nose running ability,” Zito said. “When he gets into the open field, he is much faster than many people expect and it is difficult for defenders to catch him.”Both coaches view their opponent as a very physical team.
